Mass/Volume and CPU became a thing...A thing I still hate, and I've had ample time to get used to it. Luckily it can be turned off in single player, and Servers can choose to include or dismiss it. SMALL UPDATE Jan 2016 - Check comments for details!

[ SUMMARY ] :
Space Engineers meets some StarMade and the exploration aspects of Shores of Hazeron.
I DON'T RECOMMEND buying this game right now, unless you're a HARDCORE FAN of sandbox and space games. I really mean that. Don't say you weren't warned.
I DO RECOMMEND watchlisting or following it if you like sandbox games in general. 
If you want more details, read further to understand.

[ BACKGROUND AND DISCLAMERS ]:
- Me and Empyrion: 
I got to know Empyrion through Scott Manley's Youtube Channel 2 weeks before the Steam Early Access Release, and decided that I would most definitely give it a go.
I went through ~97% of the game - I got all the resources I need and explored (probably) everything, but didn't build a Capital Ship yet.

- The Team: 
Empyrion is made by 3 indie devs. They pushed through a failed kickstarter, and here is the (early) result. They seem nice, and determined.

- This Review:
I'll first describe the game with as little personal notes as possible, and in the end I'll give my take on whatever I find necessary. This way, I save both your time and mine! :)

[ REVIEW ] :

> INTRODUCTION:
Your capital ship crashes on an alien planet. Left with a escape pod, you must gather resources and craft your way back to space.
Crafting, mining, building, hunting, surviving, running for your life when things go wrong. You'd like that, wouldn't you?
Empyrion provides a very immersive and fresh experience for those who like survival and sandbox games.

> GAME FEATURES:

SURVIVING is your first priority and your constant goal in Empyrion. You must find Water to generate Oxygen, hunt, scavange or forage for food, and find Promethium Ore to make Fuel to power all your operations!

MINING is crucial. You'll need to find resource deposits and strike the earth in order to build your base, vehicles and personal items. Mining is done by equipping your drill and digging - vehicles don't mine yet.

CRAFTING and BUILDING is a main part of the game. Much like Space Engineers, every final item is comprised of components which you must craft first. Removing a block will return its components, so remember to bring your Removal Tool to rip those expensive components from ships and bases you find in your expeditions!
Building your base is straightforward, and can end up looking pretty nice.

VEHICLES are critical for survival, exploration and progress. You can build a hovering Ground Vehicle, Small Vessels for interplanetary and atmospheric flights (as well as small-scale combat and raids), or Capital Vessels for (not yet implemented) intergalatic travel and serious combat operations.

COMBAT can happen on ground or in space. You can also be inside a ship or on foot, which makes things great: what if you leave your ship, but get flanked or surprised by the enemy?
You can also hunt wildlife for food and resources. 

The EXPLORATION vibe is definitely there. Even on initial release, you can't help but wonder what awaits you when you look at the night sky - or when seeing a weird building from a distance when you're still a survivor with just a escape pod. Maybe you could cannibalize or take over whatever that thing is, and turn it against your enemies (or against the unsuspecting wildlife)?
It's something I was looking forward in a survival sandbox space game for ages.

> GAME ASPECTS:

GRAPHICS: Very good for an indie game, but could definitely look better. Yet, I wasn't bothered by it.

SOUND:  Decent, but needs mastering, attention and variety - which are probably planned.

INTERFACE: Simple and straightforward, if you have played any similar games you'll be ready to go in minutes. The lack of a tutorial or proper in-game instructions WILL make things harder and more tiresome for non-hardcore fans. Be ready.

GAMEPLAY: Survive, mine, craft, build, fly. The gameplay and progression already feels nice, and the game doesn't take you by the hand. You're free to do whatever, whenever, however you decide.

BUGS AND ISSUES: There was a big number of release issues and bugs, some people even had their savegames corrupted or fallen out of the world. I didn't experience anything gamebreaking like that, but there's a lot of minor things that can get on the way of your fun. Still, it feels more polished than many Early Access titles I've played.

> PERSONAL NOTES:

= Positive:
- Regarding GAMEPLAY: Even though story and quests/missions are planned, I love how YOU choose where to go. 
There's an obvious way to go about things ("now I need X ore that's only available on Y planet in order to build Z item"), but you can ignore that and end up getting end-game gear by your own means and creativity. I REALLY hope this doesn't change with development.

- Random, non-scripted "events": Sometimes, circumstance might surprise you. You might be distracted and hear a weird noise, and a squad of drones are coming for you..and you forgot to craft a better gun and more ammo. This sort of stuff is what could potentially make Empyrion the best space sandbox out there, but it only happened one time..and I was probably lucky.

-  Currently, I believe food and oxygen requirement is well balanced: you won't have to run every 5 minutes back to base, but if you neglect your needs you might find yourself in deep trouble. Which is always fun.

- The game has a good selection (for an Alpha) of weapons. Choices for personal weapons include Assault Rifle, Sniper, Rocket Launcher and Laser Rifle, and ships have both (automatic/manual) Turrets and fixed weapons like the Gatling Gun, Rocket Launcher, Plasma Cannon or Rail Gun.

= Negative:
- The Unknown: There's a LOT of work to be done before it makes sense to buy and play this game. How commited is the team? What is the roadmap and milestones? Will the annoying stuff ever get fixed? There's a lot of questions like these, which are critical for EA titles to answer first.

- Annoying bugs/half-made features: Crafting takes a LOT (and I mean, A LOT) of time and requires you to manually craft EVERY SINGLE COMPONENT. Removing blocks take AGES. Mouse-wheel doesn't work. Flight model feels bad. And so on, and so forth. This makes playing the game rather painfully after the first hour or so. Is player convenience a priority?

- Space-Flight and Space-Combat must be redone from scratch. Both as an astrounaut or in a Small Ship, space-flight is terrible and space combat is insanely bad. Getting near an enemy in space will break your controls and make you lag and wonder what happened.

- Community, Hype and Fanboying: This kills games. I've seen criticism be bashed simply due to hype or 'fandom'. There's a real HUGE amount of things to be done and fixed, and dodging/dismissing feedback and criticism is not the way to go. I didn't see much developer interaction (on Steam forums), and I hope people get more of it.

> CONCLUSION:
The core concept and gameplay from this Early Access title definitely deserves to be noted and followed, but it doesn't make sense to buy it yet - unless you're really, REALLY into it.
People who played the very first moments (before building an actual base, vehicles, and getting to space) loved it - and I did too. But after these ~2 first hours, the current state of the game presents itself.

There's A LOT of work to be done in Empyrion, more than people seem think or talk about. There's many critical issues to be fixed or developed, and it's still unknown wether the ACTUAL content (planned storyline and progression) will make any sense. There's no human/alien 'sentient' NPCs or any trace of a story/quest system, and the space part of the game is really terrible and not developed at all. This is why I can't recommend you to jump head-first into it.

Therefore, put your expectations in line, take a deep breath, and make your choice.
Thanks for reading! :)

- Physics—what physics?

- Flight model—what flight model?

(It's been brought to my attention that I should point out there technically is a so-called flight model. Sadly, there's no real sense of mass or weight. Never was, and neither the "flight model" nor atmospheric engines that were added with it changed this. I say this as a flight sim fan who thinks Space Engineers and No Man's Sky both did a decent fakery job with flight, and I would have been fine with something similar in Empyrion.)

If you just want to build stuff or walk around on some same-y alien worlds, it's hard to say Empyrion isn't worth twenty bucks. It's huge with lots of moving parts. If you're looking for a deep game with polished (or even competent) survival and action mechanics, investing time in Empyrion might leave you some combination of irritated, bored and sad.

It is like Space Engineers, except with much less emphasis on the engine, and much more on the gameplay.

- While Space Engineer has a custom engine, Empyrion runs on Unity.
- While Space Engineer has pretty, shiny graphics, Empyrion has low definition store-bought assets.
- While Space Engineer has a single playfield with seamless, no-trick, transitions from space to planets, Empyrion has disctint playfields, with square planetary maps and hard, loading screen, transitions.
- While Space Engineer has a complex but brittle physic engine, Empyrion has a very basic but robust one. No block deformation, no piston and rotor, just ships flying and colliding like solid bricks (but without the inertia).
- While Space Engineer is aimless, [b]Empyrion has both a nicely tuned progression and an enjoyable gameplay loop[/b].

By progression, I don't only mean the artificial locking of technologies into an XP eating skill tree, but also the more organic usual way of having harsher biomes provide new material, needed for higher tech blocks, enabling you to reach further places.

The gameplay loop starts, as with most survival, with you dying to nearly everything, and barely able to scrounge tiny amount of ore. Then eventually managing to build the barest of ground vehicle, enabling you to harvest faster and more safely, then upgrading it and your homebase bits by bits, then eventualy moving to a tiny flying ship, reaching for the moon, getting the special metals you need to build a mothership, at which point the gameplay start having less emphasis on mining and more on raiding dungeons to loot epic weapons.

Empyrion has POI, which stands for Point of Interests, which are computer controlled bases, and more or less act like MMO dungeons. First you'll need to destroy their outter turrets with your fighter ship, then enter on foot, blasting aliens and doors, emptying loot crates, eventually destroying the core to disable the whole base and allow dismantling it. These POI usually respawn after half a day, so that even on busy servers starter planets you'll find enough pristine ones.

Details may vary, as you're free to handle them however you want: Some POI are friendly and can be looted with no fight. You may prefer to start the attack with a landbound hover ship, or with a turret covered capital ship, on foot hiding behind hills, via tunnel you dug, etc.. You may want to attack with disposable ships, then once the exterior is safeish, bring your bigger vehicle to act as a respawn, requip, and loot drop point. Sometimes you may cheat through interior fights by sneaking a specially designed super small ship. Or expend enough heavy munitions to bluntly blow through several layers of steel with your heavy ship-mounted weapons until you blow the base core. POIs are filled with enemy spawners, so you need to either explode each spawner you find, or blow up the endroom core, to pacify it. And usually the end room has some epic loot in red/purple containers, with obviously more difficult POI offering higher rewards. After the initial progression, I found most of my game time spent exploring those POI, which is a much more fun endgame activity than other similar games have. Even though the FPS part isn't on par with a pure FPS game, its integration with the rest of the game made it meaningful and rewarding.

Of course there is PvP for those who like them, with often both PvE and PvP playfields on the same server, which helps with not having newcomers not being steamrolled by vets on arrivals. But sadly, as with most PvP survival, it's actually less about player versus player and more about offline raiding, using whatever exploit is available at the moment.

[b]So, while the technical part of the game leave to be desired, I appreciated how the developper delivered an actual game instead of an empty sandbox.[/b]

I mean, even elements which you'd though purely cosmetic such as furniture actually have gameplay impact! (shower cleanse radiation and hypo/hyper thermia, sofa provides stamina boost, toilets relieves from the effect of eating unsanitary food, etc...)

Players can build constructions like bases or even ships, using a piecemeal block by block style of construction. As long as the vehicle or base meets certain requirements such as having an engine, thrusters, or whatever, it means the player has complete freedom to design insanely complex, functioning projects. What’s more, destruction in the game is also piecemeal, so a poorly designed ship that has exposed critical components could be taken out by a single explosion. This creates a cool incentive for the player to design tactically and efficiently.

So needless to say, the game is complex. Like, insanely complex. All the usual sandbox survival tropes are there; a need to harvest food, mine resources, construct buildings and so forth, all while braving hostile lifeforms on the planet. But Empyrion really takes that to the max with the depth and complexity of resources needed to construct larger projects. This isn’t new for survival games of course, but Empyrion has it in spades. On top of that, there is also a tech tree to unlock newer and better technology blueprints, resulting in even more complex constructions. This leads to a situation where building a large project requires a lot of time in what will be a significant grind-fest, but it also makes the payoff that much more rewarding.

I never heard of this game until update 1.8, which was when it started appearing in my recommended feed on Steam. I was hesitant to pick the game up at $20 seeing some of the reviews mention glaring issues, however the overall experience I've had has been phenomenal.

A word of caution before I go into more detail: this game is prone to bugs and crashes, make sure you backup your save data regularly.

To start of, the one aspect this game excels at is the sense of exploration. The system for generating structures utilizes a blueprint system wherein both players and Eleon can assign a "POI" to it for the game to have a chance of spawning in. Essentially this creates near infinite replayability as each game you create will always be unique as you explore a vast range of structures. A key point to understand though is certain structures spawning are contingent on the planet type, thus requiring you to explore the galaxy in order to experience every one of them.

Planets are also pseudo random generated in the sense that specific planet types are governed by the type of star system. For example, ocean and ice planets won't spawn in star systems with a high heat output and lava planets won't spawn in low heat systems. The amount of light a planet receives is also affected by the luminosity of the star, so if you set up camp near a neutron star you can expect to receive very little light from it.

Luminosity has little impact on gameplay as the only object affected by it is solar panels. Surprisingly planets do have a day/night cycle caused by the planet itself spinning rather than the approach some games take by having the sun orbit the planets. This means any space station constructed with fixed solar panels will have an infinite source of solar power.

Empyrion utilizes a blocked based building system with two sizes. Hover vessels and small vessels utilize the smaller block set while capital vessels and bases utilize the large block set. Despite the limitations of a block based building system the vast array of block shapes at your disposal and a deco block system means the only limitation is your creativity. It is entirely possible to recreate iconic ships such as the Normandy from Mass Effect or the Tachi from The Expanse, if you have the time and patience to do so.

One final pro to note is the integration of the Steam Workshop into the game. Eleon fully understand that the primary reason behind Empyrion's success is the dedicated community releasing some of the most intricate and power creations on the workshop. This is supported by the ability to outright spawn in blueprints by providing enough resources rather than needing to follow a hologram guide in recreating the design. If you have the time, definitely check out some of the creations from Artemis and Spanj.

Now onto the issues with the game...

As noted in several other reviews Empyrion lacks the necessary polish required for a game in a full release stage. This is evident by the mess that is the PDA system which contains: inventory, quest logs, local map, system map, galaxy map, codex information, blueprints, and the tech tree. The most egregious entry is the quest system as the overall formatting is reminiscent of early 2000s design. In time you'll learn to navigate the PDA effectively, however it's in desperate need of a redesign.

Another issue becomes evident as you advance through missions. The implementation is rather rudimentary as each step in a mission can and will break if you fail to pass the highly constrained trigger. In some instances a mission might completely break or repeat itself regardless of actions taken by the player. Eleon have even acknowledge the missions are an issue by allowing players to debug complete steps so at the very least you can complete a broken mission.

Animations and sound are areas in dire need of an overhaul as well since both lack depth and complexity we'd expect as standard for games in 2022. The sound system especially appears to only be 4 or 5 layers deep with frequent cutting the more densely packed the area you're in is. Animations tend to break often as well or are lazily implemented as you'll soon see when encountering your first NPC.

The overall graphics and models are mediocre at best with both having a mixture of high and low quality. The graphics are of the same quality as games released in the early 2000s with low res textures completely dominating your attention over the few high res textures. Hitbox models also rarely line up with the actual textures meaning you'll frequently hit blocks with your weapons despite have a clear line of sight.

Other issues include the rather simplistic AI, poor weapon integration, inconsistent difficulty, inconsistent rendering (hello random trees), basic multiplayer framework, extremely basic economy, and an unintuitice tutorial.



To sum everything up, Empyrion is a diamond in the rough that is consistently being updated and improved. For an indie game studio Eleon have produced a game that I feel provides a better experience than some AAA titles released in the past year.

Overall I'd recommend fans of the sci-fi genre to definitely pick this game up. While fairly rough at the time of publishing this review its definitely worth adding to your collection and seeing what Eleon is capable of doing.

Full disclosure: I received this product free from a generous Steam user whom I am thankful toward. That user has no ties to the developer which I am aware of, nor do I. I was not asked to review the product. It simply sates my OCD to do so.

[h1]I all but wrote this genre off until Empyrion.[/h1]

I'm one of those heretics who was bored by Minecraft, ARK, and The Forest, Different people enjoy different things, and for some, crafting/survival games are largely focused on the survival. For me, the crafting is what I love the focus to be on. I need a purpose aside from aesthetics to craft the stuff, the stuff has to interest me, and once crafted, I need to enjoy what I crafted. The aforementioned games don't appeal to me for that reason, while Subnautica totally does. It was the first crafting/survival game I liked (Terraria was decent at times, too). However, all the rest I either played or watched on YouTube turned me off on the genre. I had given up on it.

[h1]Arsenal Excellence[/h1]
Empyrion has many weapons to craft, Unlike many of these games, you get guns, and the game doesn't make you wait until 20-30 hours in to get them and have a decent ammo supply. Heck, you start with a pistol. There's only one melee weapon: the chainsaw, and it's intended for cutting down trees, really. The shooting mechanics are okay, though hardly on par with any "legit" first person shooter. It works well enough, though, and shooting a pack of space raptors to death with well-placed headshots whilst running backwards is pretty fun each time, despite its simplicity in mechanics.

You can craft several basic versions of pistols, shotguns, assault rifles, a pulse rifle, a minigun, and quite a few more. The guns worked quite nicely, and were pretty fun to wield. I will reiterate that this is not a technical gunplay marvel, but I had a nice time here.

POI's, or "points of interest," are locations you can visit, typically filled with enemies and goodies, some of which are impossible to build and can only be found in these or bought at traders, such as night vision goggles (so good), armor mods that give you defense against extreme cold, etc. If you take out the "core" of the base, you can even break down the entire base for scrap to use in building whatever you like! These bases seem to always have multiple turrets which can kill you very, very easily, even on the lowest of difficulties, so you might wait until you have an SV...more on those later.

[h1]As Difficult as You Want it to Be[/h1]
This game is not masochistic torture porn like a lot of crafting/survival games. Or at least, it doesn't have to be. There's a difficulty slider you can fiddle around with when opening the game, letting you make enemies more powerful or weaker, giving yourself fancy goodies when you start or beginning with next to nothing (I actually did that one.), etc. There is quite a lot of customization and it allows people with different interests to have an experience closer to what will make them happy, as opposed to a uniform experience that will please some and alienate others. It gives you a level of freedom that is refreshing for the genre, though I do realize a few of these sorts of games have that feature. So for those who want to have a hellish time, you can do that...heck, you could even start yourself on a planet with no oxygen and terrible starting supplies if you want to really fight to live.

On the topic of difficulty and player preference, yes, you do drop everything you're carrying when you die. That tends to really annoy me a lot in games. I love making progress, and losing all my stuff I had on me is aggravating. The good news is that your items are marked on your HUD, they stick around in a little box where you died for about 25 minutes or so, you can respawn within maybe 100 yards or so of where you died by choice, and as long as you didn't go on a total suicide mission the first time, it should be easy enough to get your stuff back. I played well over 100 hours, and there's only one time I couldn't get my stuff back...and that was because I didn't know how to use the jump jets (jetpack) to move around in space...heh, more on space later.

[h1]Mine, All Mine[/h1]
I hate grind in games; despise it. That said, sometimes you can find a grind that mesmerizes you and sweeps you off your feet. Perhaps not everyone can experience that, but for me, it was the mining in this game. A friend and I would mine, and while drilling ore, we kept wanting to stop, but we just couldn't. We were watching the rock walls reshape and the ore pieces fall in chunks on the ground, and kept digging and digging. We actually hollowed out a massive ore deposit (just the two of us) with the starting drills, which took us about 3 hours. It went on a little longer than we would have liked, but we couldn't help ourselves. If mopping blood in Viscera Clean-Up Detail mesmerizes you or gives you a satisfying feeling, this might too, because it felt similar in terms of the level of satisfaction for me.

Later on, you can build an "HV," which is short for Hover Vessel. Essentially, it's a hovercraft, and they move quite quickly, serving as a nice means of speedy transport, and more importantly, slap some level 1 drills on the front in a smart layout, and you'll be tearing through the rocks and ore, automatically collecting it in a box/device on your HV in huge quantities. Zip back over to your base you've built, which is quick and easy, since you can move so fast in your HV, and store your goodies in boxes you can build and label with some nice storage space inside.

[h1]Space, the Final Frontier[/h1]
Small Vessels, or "SV"s, are essentially space ships. You can build them, though you will need some parts, fuel, and oxygen to leave the planet. You can spend dozens of hours on a planet with plenty to do, and then when you build a ship, you design it yourself. It's actualy not difficult at all. While you could import a design easily, I preferred to make my own. As utilitarian as I am in these, there was this amazing since of pride and delight that I had from successfully constructing a tiny, laughably-designed SV, getting it to take off, making modifications, and finally leaving orbit! It was a total thrill and I was wide-eyed and giddy. I will never forget how good it felt getting into space, and just sitting there with my engines off, floating. Then I look, and there's the moon that's always been in the sky. Well, I fly right toward that sucker!

I brought plenty of oxygen, and I stocked an adorable little mini-fridge with snacks for my trip. I found new ores that couldn't be mined on the starting planet, so I happily mine those, and rare equipment now becomes easier to make, improving what I could craft greatly. There were more points of interest there, too, which was fun, and a bunch of blue crystals. Now I'm master of the planet, [i]and[/i] the moon. Mind you, this is dozens of hours of content for me between the planet and moon. Finally, I decide I'll go to another planet, so I design a Capital Vessel "CV." It's a warp-capable ship bigger than a house, and you can lay it out how you like! It was daunting, but I did it and loved the simple but useful end product. You can even make a landing bay and park your HVs and SVs inside it to transport to other planets!

Finally, I warp to another world...and I'm basically done. I can go to other planets and moons, but there's nothing left to do except get more stuff. There is no new tech for me to build, and without honest story objectives, I'm essentially "done" in my playthrough. It feels a bit disappointing and empty at that point, but I'm a hard-ass with games, and will whole-heartedly say that I had a fantastic time with what there is to do in Empyrion. I'd play through it again from scratch sometime, I imagine. The usefulness and feeling of progress makes the game for me, and if you liked that about Subnautica, Empyrion might just be for you.

Empyrion: Galactic Survival is an early access open world space and survival game developed and published by Eleon Game Studios. You play as a human who blasts from space into earth in a survival pod. You can explore the planet, survive, gather resources, build bases and build things like gardens and fuel tanks, and build space ships. This review will cover the content, the developers engagement on the project, and the negatives.

[h1] [b] Content [/b] [/h1]
Empyrion features a ton of content for the player. People refer to this game as 'No Man's Sky, but with 3x the content' and while I have not played that game, I can safely say this game successfully incorporates a variety of factors including survival, building, and exploration. But, evidently at this stage the developers have focused on more exploration and building than survival because there is an abundance of building and resources and a lot of planets to explore, but it severely lacks in survival elements. At the beginning of the game upon exiting your survival pod, the game provides you a play of a very well-structured tutorial. It teaches you the complete basics on surviving, how to gather resources, how to build bases, and how to build a ship. They are also very descriptive, sometimes in borderline with too much detail, but for the most part you learn a lot from it.

I will briefly explain each component. The survival component includes a health bar, food bar, oxygen bar, and stamina bar. Each of these represent different things, so health is your characters health, oxygen depletes when you are in space or underwater, food is a necessity. Food automatically depletes, which so does stamina, but stamina can regenerate over time. I played only on a Player vs. Environment server and survival is quite basic, defending against a very scarce variety of enemies. Resources are large, but there is not an abundance of them and regular meteorites crash into planets providing resources. Each planet has different resources, which of some overlap, which means there is a good sense of freedom to explore and travel to get those materials. 

Planets are diverse and beautiful. They all have different attributes like different environment colours, different terrain, and size varies. The interesting concept is that despite playing on a PvE server, some planets are PvP so if you are looking for the best of both worlds, the game allows you to experience it. Spaceships are disparate and are highly detailed. There are three types of spaceships, Capital Vessel, Small Vessel, and Hover Vessel. All have different attributes including external size, internal size and how much can you fit in there. I love the spaceships because they are not overly hard to build if you follow the tutorial, there are an abundance of spaceships thanks to the Steam Workshop, and they look beautiful.

Empyrion also incorporates a skill tree. This skill tree allows you to progress through levels and earn upgrade points to unlock better cockpits, or better weapons, or better ships, and so forth. There is plentiful amounts of skills, which differ, and provide a refreshing aspect as you progress further into the game. Notably, these skills include unlocking various things to help you base build. For instance, a base needs a constructor to transfer resources into materials or food, which also needs a fuel tank and a generator to power it. In other words, bases require different components to expand and operate. Base building is a great feature in this game and I think this really nails down the popularity with the game.

[h1] [b] Developer Engagement [/b] [/h1]
The developers are incredibly ambitious and understand it cannot execute a roadmap similar to zombie survival games in which there is too much content over fixing and improving the core and performance of the game. Therefore, I have noticed that these developers are active and regularly respond to community queries and very regularly post updates on the status of their roadmap. For instance, today they put out a survey based off events at Gamescom which asks the community how much they play the game, single player or multiplayer, and what large feature do they want and what small feature do they want. In other words, it seems there core vision for the game is still in effect but they want to implement features and fixes based on community wants, which is a great touch to this game. 

[h1] [b] Negatives [/b] [/h1]
Per the early access part of this title, I understand that a lot of features are relatively basic. For instance, there are no gun reloading animations and there are very few enemies to combat in PvE. Furthermore, performance is subpar as I have noticed FPS from 23 in drilling mines to 40 when flying. My graphical settings were on fastest instead of best, so the developers do need to further optimise the game. I am looking forward to watching this game progress in development.

[h1] [b] Conclusion [/b] [/h1]
Empyrion is a strong early access title. It features an abundance of content that stem from survival to exploration to building. There is also a large amount of planets that have differing attributes to defining features from diverse resources to one planet being PvE and others being PvP. The developers are very responsive and driven to further work on this game. I did not notice any bugs, but I did notice the basic nature of many features and the lack in optimisation of performance. At $19.99, if you play with friends, I totally recommend this game. If you play single player, don't expect as much enjoyment but do expect at least a solid 30 hours of play. 

[h1] [b] Rating [/b] [/h1]
I do not rate early access titles.

[h1] [b] Pros [/b] [/h1]
	- The elegantly designed spaceships.
	- The entire mechanic of the game in which relates to exploration.
	- Disparate planets that differ.
	- Steam workshop.

[h1] [b] Cons [/b] [/h1]
	- Many features are simple, which of some need to further expanded on.

[b]Empyrion - Galactic Survival[/b] is a space open world survival game with randomly generated planets and with heavy crafting and building elements. When I say open world, I really mean it, in the sense that if you have some sort of spacecraft you can fly across space and land on any planet you choose. 

The game offers you two different game modes at the moment, creative and survival. Creative is what you’d expect, build and do whatever you like, your imagination is your limit. As for the survival mode, you’re able to choose different seeds to create your worlds and you can also choose where you’d like to begin your adventure, in a more friendly planetnet with a breathable atmosphere or in a more deadly desert planet that is perfect for hardcore players. Since I’m not really someone who is very creative or that enjoys building, survival is always what I go for in these types of games.

[h1][b]The core:[/b][/h1]

On survival mode you’ll find yourself looking for oxygen, food and other resources. The game provides a pretty in-depth tutorial covering survival, base and ship building. Food can be acquired by hunting, gathering or farming and it can get spoiled. This can be prevented by either cooking or by storing food on a fridge. The oxygen can be obtained by placing a O2 generator on water, which then will begin producing bottles of oxygen. Resource gathering is pretty simple since you start with the tools needed, simply aim and click with the right tool to the place you want to mine. Still, every tool requires a certain type of charges to use so be careful not to waste all your charges before you’ve gathered the resources needed to craft more. One thing I really like about the game is the fact that when you discover a ore deposit, it will be marked on your map which is a 3D representation of the planet you’re in. If you check the map, you can also see how many, and what type of deposits you still haven’t found on the planet.

Empyrion also has some other mechanics which make it somewhat more challenging and engaging, such as stamina, a jetpack and blueprint “trees”. You use stamina while sprinting so you have to keep an eye out in case you’re being followed by some mobs and run out of stamina. Nonetheless, you still have your jetpack which, despite making you unable to run, allows you to escape tricky situations including when you get trapped while mining downwards (never dig downwards). By performing simple actions such as gathering resources or crafting you’ll gain experience points, these will allow you to level up and gain points which you can use to unlock certain blueprints/recipes on some sort of “skill tree” menu. 

Assuming you have the required blueprints and materials, crafting is pretty straight simple since the game tells you what a certain item needs in order to be crafted. If farming is an option in a survival game, I tend to go that route, thus I must say I quite enjoy how farming plays out in Empyrion. Basically you place “growing plot” blocks, place whatever seed you want and then you have to make sure that a light source is 2 blocks above it. The plant won’t grow immediately of course so you can go on another errands while you wait for your crops to be ready to harvest.

One minor complaint I have with the game is the fact that there are no reload animations. Still, I’m sure this is due to the Early Access nature of the title and that is something that will be implemented soon. That said, combat is serviceable at best, you just aim and shoot, the weapons have pretty much no recoil or authentic feel to them and I believe this is something that should be worked on. Despite the dynamic day and night cycle (where if you look at the sky you can see the other planets far off), I didn’t notice any change in mobs behaviour which kind of disapointed me.

[h1][b]Verdict:[/b][/h1][list]
[*]Huge amount of things to craft
[*]Space and planetary exploration
[*]Overall decent performance - except a few slowdowns when visiting new areas
[*]Well done ambient and background sound effects + pretty great main menu theme
[*]Detailed tutorial, which welcomes newcomers
[*]Dated visuals - as far as I care, the game looks somewhat dated
[/list]

Empyrion - Galactic Survival is the closest thing to what I want from a game that combines space and planetary exploration. Even if you’re like me and don’t like building, you can just import creations from other players from the Workshop, in the form of blueprints, and get them in your world. I highly recommend you check this one out if you’re into space exploration and survival! I’m looking forward to see how this one develops.

Empyrion has many depth levels for all player needs. The basic survival and crafting systems are friendly enough, as they have many quality of life and automation features. For those in need for a deeper experience, there are systems such as custom circuit-building with logic ports, individual configuration of each machine behavior, control groups and advanced parts. The survival aspect of the game is great....it has some of the usual aspects of most sandboxes such as mining, leveling, crafting, farming, base/ship building and exploration.  Most of these are similar to other games so I will touch on each of these briefly.

[h1]Mining[/h1]
Mining is done by scouting out the planet and a scanner locating deposits. Once a suitable deposit of ore is found you use a drill to extract the ore. It does take some time to mine much like most sandboxes, but oddly it seems more satisfying in Empyrion to me than other games even though I cannot pinpoint exactly why. Once you are done with the drill you can then press "T" to pickup the mined ore to take back to base from processing said ore into ingots.

[h1]Leveling/Tech Tree[/h1]
There is leveling and a tech tree that go hand-in-hand.  Basically, you start out at level 1 and as you do certain tasks suchs as mining, building or farming you gain experience towards the next level. You also gather points that you can spend learning new things to craft via the Tech Tree in the game. This is broken up into various tabs such as Hover Vessel, Space Vessel, Capital Vessel, Base, Decor and a few others. So each time you level you get to learn new craftable items. While this is not something new, it is still great fun!

At the start of the game you get a simple "Survival Constructor" and as you progress through the game you gain access to create more advanced constructors.  The more advanced constructors are slightly faster and the top tier constructor allows for auto-assembly of items by automatically constructing pre-requisite items for whatever item you may want to build. It saves quite a bit of time.

If you like building ships, buy this game and play it. I can't overstate how amazing it is for that kind of play.

After a few hours I had reliable sources of oxygen, food, fuel, and crafting materials. I made my way into the air, then into space, and built a capital ship. It was ugly and utilitarian, but I learned some important things about design as I went. I took it into another system and beat down an enemy drone boat or two, which was fun the first couple of times. The problem there is that a cheap, agile fighter with a few gatling guns can easily wipe out any enemy space force. Why bother with an expensive capital vessel? I started to get bored.

In disgust I went back to my home planet and gathered materials, then started playing around with new ship ideas.

It. Was. A. Fucking. Blast. 

You have no idea. And not a short term blast...this lasted for a couple hundred hours. I wrote down ideas and drew models of ships and built them. It was like when Minecraft was new, except you get to actually fly the machine you've built.

Instead of building a bunch of specific types of block, you have a generic type that can be customized however you want. A steel cube can become a cylinder, or a curved corner piece, or dozens of others. It's a great way of doing things. Forget having to craft steps or whatever. Empyrion puts few barriers between you and the expression of your ideas. Empyrion - Galactic Survival (which I'll refer to as E: GS from now on) is an early access survival game (stay with me here) currently taking place across four planets and in Space. In E: GS you begin your fight for survival on a barren, desert planet called Omicron next to your escape pod which is beyond repair. In the distance you see the remains of your Capital ship and exploring the planet not only reveals ore deposits but it also reveals strange structures and hostile drones wandering the planet. 

Now you're probably thinking why on Earth should anyone be interested in yet another Early Access game, simply put E: GS does something no other survival game, to my knowledge, has done; it gives you three entire planets to explore as well as the ability to travel around in Space. The next thing that might spring to mind for you is how is this any different to Space Engineers? E: GS is fundementally different to SE, E: GS is more focused on the Survival side of things whereas SE is more focused on the creativity in building side of things, plus SE doesn't have planets. 

Since some of this game's issues are more serious than others I'll split my negative section into two, the first section having a much larger impact on my overall verdict than the second.

+E: GS manages to add something new to an already crowded genre and it does it reasonably well
+You're given a great deal of freedom in regards to crafting bases, vehicles etc. So long as you have the key components for whatever it is you're building (key components are listed by the starting block for each thing) you can add whatever you want and make it look however you want it to look and still be able to use it, though practicality is often something worth considering with vehicles
+Speaking of starting blocks, each large project (i.e. a base, a ground vehicle, a small cruiser or a capital cruiser) has a corresponding starter block which provides the ship's foundations. A starter block gives you access to a menu detailing your project's stats, such as power consumption, but it also gives you a list of the components which your project MUST have in order to function, such as a fuel tank or a cockpit
+There are already a lot of different items which can be crafted ranging from tools and weapons to thrusters and generators
+The three planets are all very different to each other, each one with its own distinct appearance as well as different creatures and plants
+The game's controls are, for the most part, good though using the mouse for turning in vehicles sometimes feels a tad bit sluggish
+The devs are already updating the game frequently, hopefully that'll continue throughout the game's development
+E: GS already features multiplayer and there are plans to improve it over the course of the game's development process
+The four planets are procedurally generated. What does this mean? While the four planets will always be the same, everything on the planet's surface will be randomized everytime you play with a different seed, e.g. where resources can be found and where enemies spawn

+/-E: GS' graphics aren't awful but they aren't exactly easy on the eye either, it doesn't take away from the game as a whole (hence it's in the neutral section) but considering the fact there are currently no solid plans to improve the game's graphics it is somewhat disappointing

[h1]Major Negatives:[/h1]

-Crafting items is unbelievably tedious, which is a problem in a game where so much of the gameplay is based around crafting things. Every major item, such as a generator, requires several different components for you to make it, some of these components require other components to make them, all of your components require some sort of ingot or equivalent item and each ingot has to be made from the ore. At face value it isn't awful but when you add into the mix the fact that you can only craft one type of item at a time, the fact that most things take between 5-20 seconds to craft one unit of and the fact that the crafting machines have small inventories for you to store raw materials as well as completed items it starts to become clear why E: GS' crafting system is its biggest problem
-The four currently available worlds feel empty, apart from the occasional hostile structure or drone and the creatures that inhabit these worlds there is literally nothing to see on the worlds other than the ore in the ground. Futhermore, to counteract this ore deposits are very spread out, a nice idea in theory but frustrating when a round trip to get more ore takes 10 minutes while you're still on foot
-Despite the fact that silica is one of the most important ingredients in crafting (used in some capacity to make pretty much every major component) it's seemingly incredibly rare which is rather frustrating when you run out of it and have no means of finding more

[h1]Minor Negatives:[/h1]

-Unlike in Space Engineers, colliding with terrain in a vehicle has no effect on the terrain though it does still damage your vehicle
-There's currently very little in the way of character customisation
-Sound effects are pretty hit and miss as to whether or not they sound realistic and apart from on the main menu there's no music in the game
-The in-game menu can't be accessed while the game is paused which means if you wish to tweak your settings or controls you can't do so unless you want to risk not pausing your game

Verdict:
Worth Purchasing On Sale (6.5/10)

E: GS is a good survival game which gives you a lot of freedom when it comes to building things and surviving but it's currently let down by its tedious crafting system.  E: GS has a lot of potential and hopefully the game will only get better as time goes on but for now, wait until a sale unless you're willing to look past the game's major issues.

I have been playing this game a long time and have logged 670 hours on it. When I first started playing Empyrion, it was still in Early Access. There were plenty of bugs, but enough of a game that it was playable and enjoyable. 

In the beginning the game was all about survival and it had some great elements of a survival game. The player starts with nothing, and had to find food and shelter pretty quick to survive the deadly predators and the radiation storms. Next they'd build a motorcycle to get around a bit faster and start to find ore deposits. It took forever to dig out the ore with the survival tool, but it felt balanced. It was unlikely the player had been able to get a real weapon, so they were limited to the survival tool’s limited weapon abilities. While mining the player had to worry about spiders or something following them into the ore cave and attacking them. At the same time the player had to scavenge for food, and might begin a farm so they'd have steady supply of food to eat. Eventually they'd get enough resources to build a hover vehicle - and the first time I started whipping around the planet in one of those, it felt amazing. You could bounce off hills to go soaring through the world. There were “bugs” that felt real. If the player wasn’t careful they could flip over and might have to take the motorcycle to go get a thruster to put on the hover vehicle’s side to give it enough torque to flip back over. You could also find yourself under water, and moving an inch at a time to the closest shore, which took forever but realistic. 
And finally with a hover vehicle the player could get to the other factions. At that time there was no galaxy, and only 3 or 4 factions. Each faction had territory on the initial planet. When the player found a faction they wouldn’t immediately trust the player and trade with them because they simply didn't trust the player yet. The player would have to kill predators in their territory or kill the faction’s enemies and gave a reputation with them. Eventually the player’s reputation rose and they were finally able to trade. Once of the most important items to buy was ammo for a multitool. The ammo was too expensive to make which made this a milestone moment in the game. The multitool allowed the player to finally retrieve blocks, allowing you to salvage crashed capital ships and other POIs of abandoned buildings, etc. 
Finding and building fuel was a challenge, which made the player appreciate the low fuel consuming hover vehicle. After many hours of playing, the player would get to build a small ship and head into orbit. There wasn't much up there, but it was exciting to go anyways, another milestone. The next step was to create a warpable vehicle. I can't remember when the small ships gained the ability, but I'm pretty sure it was only capital ships in the beginning. The cost to build the blocks for the ship was high, making the player salvage crashed ships around the planet to get the blocks to build their first beautiful capital ship. Might not be much of a ship, but it would get into orbit, and warp to the other planets in the solar system. At that time warp lines were static. You couldn't just warp to any planet in range. You had to follow the path, which made sense in some ways. If the planet was on the other side of the sun, you couldn't warp to it. The other planets didn't have much on them back then, but they did have rare resources that were needed to improve vehicles, adding shields, etc. 
All and all, going from a player that was scavenging for food and shelter, to a player flying around the solar system was a great feeling, and made a great game.

That was in the beginning. The game has had many updates since then and has suffered badly from feature creep. 
On August 5th, 2020 the game left early access. The tag “early access” allowed the many bugs in the game to be explained away as the game was not “released” yet. But upon release the game was still littered with bugs, and lacked the polish of a finished game. Almost a year later there are still major bugs in the game. Ships that collide, don’t take or cause any damage, and sometimes become “merged”. NPCs that fall when there is no gravitational field.  Or invisible barriers preventing the player from moving or salvage parts of a ship that has not completely stopped moving.
The game has a forum for submitting bugs, and I have submitted a couple dozen bugs. Some of the bugs I submitted that were clearly bugs but were being categorized as not a bug for reasons that didn’t actually make sense (like indicating there is a workaround or the bug wasn’t important enough). This is the sign of an overwhelmed team and an unpolished game suffering from numerous bugs.
But it is not all bad. A galaxy was added which was exciting and well done in my opinion. Players could now warp to any planet or system within a 30 LY range. But this is also when the game lost its survival feeling. It became very easy for a new player to get into a capital ship and start warping around the galaxy within a few hours of playing. Food could be bought from vendors at cheap prices, removing any need to farm. Ores could be bought from other traders, removing any need to mine. Salvaged weapons and armor could be sold for a disproportionately high amount of money, making it easy to survive. Although the motorcycle is still in the game, it is never used (might still be in the tutorial but that’s about it). Fuel became very cheap to buy from trading stations, allowing players to use their capital ship for all ventures, and making hover vehicle obsolete. Repairing ships became too easy – by saving a template of a completed ship, the player could take there almost completely destroyed vehicle to a trading station, get a cheap price, and instantly repair the ship back to new. For example, an almost completely destroyed capital ship could be completely repaired for less than selling one suit of heavy armour. The original survival aspect of the game and the importance of the original features became obsolete. 
In the original game, everything could be mined, retrieved, destroyed, etc. Enemy based could be captured and raided. It was an “I can do anything in here” game. As the updates came, more and more things broke that feeling. Asteroids were added. Some can be mined, but the majority (99%) can’t be mined, destroyed, or used in any way. NPCs were added that do nothing and the player can’t interact with. Space stations were being built with common blocks that can’t be damaged, captured, or destroyed, even by the strongest weapons. The game has lost a lot of the original “I can do anything in here” feeling.
Features were also being added that didn’t make sense, like satellites that are only found orbiting the star of the system. A new Data Hoarder trader was created, where you could sell the hacked data from these satellites.  But you can’t get or hack data from any other bases, ships, or NPCs, making it feel very incomplete. Similarly trading goods were added, but the game lacks an economical engine to change the prices based on supply and demand, making the trading system very simple.
So where does the game stand today? It was a beautiful survival game, well designed and had a clear objective. It has suffered badly from feature creep and bugs that should have been addressed before moving from “Early Access”. When playing, the game has a hollow feeling, like the game has lost its purpose and soul. It feels like a game that grasped for the stars and barely reached the moon.
The competition for this game would be a mix of Space Engineers, X3, and No Man’s Sky. From a quality and completed perspective though, it does not come close to any of these games. It is hopeful that the Empyrion team finds their focus again and is able to bring soul back to the game.
I've marked this not recommended only as there is no option for “its ok, but it's not what is was"

Empyrion is:

1) An inde game put together by a small team running it all by the seat of their pants.  It is not polished perfect... but it has a lot of heart and soul.

2) A survival game starting with bare hands and requiring you to manage health, hunger stamina and oxygen levels as well as combat various forms of disease and mutilation you may suffer when you fight

3) A building game where you engineer and build custom vehicles and bases with a block based system after refining materials.  With the raw materials, you can also spawn blueprints that have already been created by you or others from the workshop.  It can be fun just to go creative and spawn ships you have collected into library to explore them and try them out.

4) A harvesting game where you dig into voxel based planets and asteroids for resources. 

5) A procedural game where no two saves create the same universe.

6) An exploration game with lots of points of interest to discover both on the starting planet and in the universe that waits you when you achieve space flight.  Lots of different types of suns and planets with different characteristics.  Several factions of NPC to interact with.  Points of interest spawn randomly all over the universe.

7) A salvaging game where you can rip apart your enemies ships and bases and make them into your own creations... or sell the parts...or scrap them.  You will also find derelict ships and buildings.

8) A trading game where you can find various resources or devices and sell them to traders for profit.  Or, you can buy things from traders and sell them to other traders for profit.  Or you can make things out of your resources and sell them for profit.

9) A first person shooter game where you fight insects, zombies, aliens and military forces in contexts ranging from horror dungeon crawler to military conquest of bases.

10 ) A space ship combat game where you attack bases with your small ship to soften them up... or you go capital ship to capital ship in a massive showdown of missiles and energy weapons.

11) A good single player experience and also a decent looking multi player experience on a server setup.

12) Backed up by an incredibly good mod scenario known as "Reforged Eden" which takes the game to an even higher level of challenges and enjoyment.

13) Still being actively updated as of June 2022.

I have gotten a lot of enjoyment out of this game.    The only major thing I wish it had was the ability to walk around on your ship as it is flying (you can only fly while in the pilot seat) and the ability to command a fleet of ships that can do various tasks such as surveying a system, defending the mothership, or mining.  Those would make the game pretty much everything I could ask for.


The negative reviews I see are not entirely inaccurate... but this game has so much heart... and it has done so much with so little...that I feel like those complaints are not a deal breaker for me.  Some of the complaints require hundreds of hours playing before they become apparent.  Most will find a lot of enjoyment before that happens.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in the features I have described above.  I have not come across many games that check so many boxes.

[h1]Open World Survival meets Tower Defense[/h1] in the best 3D space adventure I’ve played so far. With realistic mining for rare elements, terraforming, exploration, & hunting; it provides a PVE experience that is a delight to play, even in early access. 

[b]State of the Art:[/b]
   Empyrion has a full suite of heavy duty tools, equipped with lights for night/cave mining & terraforming, like a futuristic drill, & a Flatten/Fill tool for terraforming. It can drill in a pinch, but it can also repair holes in your mine roof to keep spiders out. In creative mode, your jetpack flies. In survival it has limited gravity jumps that can result in injury. You start with a handgun, but the assault rifle upgrade has a powerful feel. You can add other weapons, turrets & machinery as you upgrade. The interaction of component parts just feels great!

[b]Flora & Fauna: [/b]
   With the wide variety of indigenous plants & animals; you feel like you’ve just stepped into Arthur Conan Doyle’s Lost World, or the set from Lost in Space or Guardians of the Galaxy. But, there is no cool 70’s walkman or choosing music tracks, which would probably be a welcome plus. The game soundtrack is good, but the two scores will get repetitive if you play this much. (If you saw The Martian movie you know we need more music.)
   There are edible & Medicinal plants, like Ahax fruit, Alien Spike Lemons, Space Oranges, Cobra leaves, Aloe Vera, & varieties of Alien plasma. Fearsome creatures become dinner, like the multi-headed Hydra-like Olyugh, the Desert Worm, Wood walkers who looks like Sasquatch, a warrior type AI, a baby Allosaurus & triceratops. Some are hostile, others will be if provoked.

[b]Skill Trees & Game Modes: [/b]
   You find yourself falling from the sky in an escape pod if you are lucky, or already on the ground in the pod if it glitches on loading. If you are still in freefall, you are able to steer the pod’s fall with the mouse. Once you get out of the pod you grab all your gear. The last update to 1.4.0 fixed the ability to open pods that land in water, as well as improving functionality of turrets.
   The game uses an efficient Tech tree system to allow you to unlock equipment as you earn levels which reset for each game you play & augments the rewards of the strategy & resource management needed to survive on this level. 
   Game Modes give lots of variety with Creative or Survival Modes of PVE & PVP in MP. But, within Survival worlds, at the moment you are only able to choose between the normal forest planet of Akua or the Hardcore Desert planet of Omicron. Akua is Hawaiian for “god” & definitely looks like a lost world paradise. Omicron is where the intensity picks up, with more scarcity of resources that are spread further apart, & volatile terrain. You have a seed generator for terrain variety. If you land near the drones it’s all over before it begins. The drones are real techno-beasts & you probably can’t evade them early game.

[b]Crafting: [/b]
    The crafting interface can be confusing at first. Production flows right to left with the queue on bottom. Click the template you want, to move it to the queue to be constructed. Then the new item you wanted is output into the constructor's inventory space. You can move what you want from there to your own inventory or hot-bar. 

[b]Space Travel & Vehicles: [/b]
   The game allows you to set up not only a home base on a planet or in space, but you can construct a “hover vehicle” which is a fully stocked mobile base, equipped with fridge & food facilities for mining & hunting. You can also build small aircraft & capital vessels which can equip warp-drive to visit other planets & mine asteroid fields. In MP asteroids land for mining elements. In early access only 2 planets are available, though you can see the full list on the warp map. 
   Each base/vehicle has a “starter block” with a core which emits a beacon when the power is turned on. When you build it, equip it, & power it up then prepare for an incoming drone siege that will last until you are able to dispatch drones quickly.  You must be well stocked with food before powering up that generator. This creates a game of tower defense. The drones will try to destroy the core starter block. Once you lose that block the game is for all practical purposes over, giving it a perma-death element. You have the option to restart at the location you die near your backpack. But, if drones were there, they will still be there when you respawn at half stats & they will likely kill you again before you can recover your weapon. The game also gives you the option to respawn near your base or take a fresh start, but the fresh start is a bad choice. It will put you in a falling pod with fewer resources. Best option is to exit the game & start a whole new world. You can build a clone chamber once you have a base that will set your spawn point. This is a great feature. 

[b]Mapping & Graphics: [/b]
   The game runs on much less hardware than stated. The graphics seem to be similar on my screenshots to what people who have better machines are experiencing. There’s no lag. The first day I flew the small vessels I experienced holes in my terrain, but that was cleared up by the next day’s update. The scenery is lovely, but the graphics are subpar resolution in the current access state.
   The mechanic of space travel is less well developed than the planetary aspects of the game mechanics. You experience a slideshow of backgrounds as you leave the planet’s atmosphere, enter orbit, go deep space, & finally approach a new planet. You move around in each slide, but it has a bottom of the picture. I accidentally fell off the space station in deep space. I visibly fell for a few seconds, & then my avatar just stood there among the stars at the bottom of the background scenery in a “stop the world & I’ll jump off” effect. 
   The in-game HUD utilizes a nice planetary mapping system with marker/beacons for different points of interest, like bases, rare elements, & drones. The space map needs work but does not affect the fun to be found in this great game. Visible location coordinates would be nice.	

[b]Tutorial: [/b]
   The tutorial is really just simply the PDA info displayed one subchapter at a time on the right side of the HUD as missions. The instructions will not move forward until you do that mission. Also, it won’t remember actions that you’ve done early, so you have to repeat actions to get that mission objective to progress to the next step. You can deactivate chapters in the PDA, but you will lose subchapter steps. Also, there is no pause feature in the game, & reading or opening the PDA wastes your limited O2 & food while you stand around reading a TL:DR wall of text. I hope this is a priority because it leads to frustration trying to figure out what to do as a new player. Like Elon Musk says, “If it needs a manual it is broken.” I would like to see a computer generated voice-over speaking to you from your PDA, kind of like HAL in 2001, giving you an emergency briefing to get you started on the HUD mission log. 

[b]Pros: [/b]
•	Hardcore Tower/Base Defense 
•	Workshop to share ready-made build Templates
•	Flight controls are intuitive
•	Plug & play construction 
•	Planetary exploration includes excellent game mechanics
•	Underpriced at $17.99/ many games in this tier $30.00

[b]Cons: [/b] 
•	No weather & Space Travel is subpar
•	AI (except drones) are unintelligent
•	PDA not noticeable in HUD. Lack of real Tutorial 
•	The ‘hit-boxes’ seem a bit small slowing collection

[h1]If you are dreaming of exploring planets, then Empyrion is the space sim for you. [/h1]I rate it an 8 out of 10 for survival games, with elements of tower defense & resource management. I highly recommend this game for everyone. If the tutorial is augmented & the space mechanics are perfected I will change my review to a perfect ten.

I love this game but I can’t recommend it to people

Empyrion is an ambitious, fun but deeply flawed building game. If you love building, exploring, collecting/crafting, have a good internet connection (to join a close server) and a degree of stubbornness, you’ll probably love this game. However, sooner or later the lack of polish, game-breaking bugs and lack of Dev support will undoubtedly diminish your enjoyment.

Empyrion is a survival, building game, in the likes of Minecraft and 7 Days to Die but with a focus on building hover vehicles, aircraft and spacecraft. Undoubtedly the game truly shines with its ability to let players place thrusters, generators, cockpits and fuel tanks onto a craft, then letting the player fail or fly with great satisfaction. If you’ve wanted to build a tank that trundles into bases ignoring all the return fire and melting opposition, that’s possible. If you want to fly around in a giant pizza-shaped spaceship with turrets that pop out of the pepperonis, you can do that, if you want a supervillain lair built into the side of a mountain with numerous defended escape tunnels, that’s possible too! Even if you’re not creative or too lazy to design your own creation, it’s possible to hop onto the steam workshop and download thousands of amazing designs from other players and spawn them into your game! That’s right, this game allows you to save your creations to file, fill it up with enough resources to pay for it, then spawn in another copy. This means those builds you love can be transferred between creative/single-player/multiplayer/etc as long as you have the resources to pay for them and undoubtedly this is where the game absolutely shines.

So once you’ve gotten enough food, tools and weapons to build your first craft you’ll be free to start exploring the worlds, this is where the ambition and execution fall apart, the game is capable of creating infinite, weird, wonderful, vast solar systems but after you’ve explored a few you’ll see the same stock assets, same points of interest, same craft, same unintelligent “aliens” in repeat until you’ve realised that being able to generate infinite worlds means very little if they’re just filled with the same assets. This is why I recommend playing in a server because good servers have fields filled with players, builds, additional content, shops and other interesting things to do. Otherwise single player just doesn’t have enough to do.

So this where I start going into the negatives of the game and why I can’t recommend Empyrion in this state/stage. Empyrion has been one of those game that has been in “Alpha” or a developmental stage for many, many years (around 5 years at the writing of this review) and the majority of assets/mechanics are janky, poorly implemented and feel unfinished. Game breaking bugs have been in the game for years, reported and ignored. Sometimes your base/ship will partially load in, forcing you to exit the game and load in again, as many times as it takes to make your whole base/ship appear. Perhaps you’re shooting something and run out of ammo and would rather switch weapons instead of waiting for the for 4 seconds reload time to finish, but instead, the game tries to reload the weapon you switched to and restarts the reload timer/animation again. Maybe you’ll attach a new part to your base and it’ll suddenly explode off even though structural integrity means it should be solid. Original Review;

When I first picked up Empyrion : Galactic Survival I have to admit that I wasn’t impressed.  I had been playing another very similar title for quite some time and found Empyrion to be fairly inferior when it came to the game experience as a whole.  Recently returning to Empyrion I found many changes.  Let’s just say, my first day returning to this game I put 12 hours into it.

Empyrion : Galactic Survival is one of those games that you’ll either love or hate.  It’s a game based heavily on survival where you absolutely can’t sit idle.  You can’t just put up a few walls, toss on a roof, and consider yourself safe.  If you don’t keep up with your tasks (like gathering food/oxygen) you’ll quickly find yourself dying.  In addition, resources are fairly limited so you have to continuously push yourself to explore further and further away from your comfort zone (aka. Your base).

Crafting in Empyrion is a fairly simple task, with most machines requiring you to first craft components for those machines.  Even some components require components.  While some may find this a tedious task to perform, I rather enjoied it as it gave me something to constantly be doing.   You can’t just “click” and have yourself a cockpit (for example), you actually have to build the parts for it before it can be assembled.  I enjoyed this in the other title I mentioned earlier, and I like that Empyrion has adopted this crafting style.  There is a bit of a balance problem in crafting, however, and I hope that the developers solve it in the future.  While crafting items doesn't really have this problem, crafting food seems to be a little problematic.  Take a "sandwitch", for example.  In order to make a sandwitch you need to use a salami, a bread, and a tomato.  Seperately, in total these three items contain values of 195 food, 30 health, and 30 stamina.  Together, as a sandwitch, the values are 160 food, 10 health, and 25 stamina.  Thus you would be an idiot to craft a sandwitch as you are loosing a lot of food value in a game where food is always a struggle.  In crafting you would expect that a crafted item would have an equal, if not a higher, value than what you are putting into it.  This is one small way in which crafting recipes are currently "broken" in empyrion, but hopefully will be fixed.

In returning to the game I also found myself dealing with a new leveling system as well.  Each time you gain a level you unlock some basic building block recipes and get points to unlock more complex crafting recipes.  You have to spend your points wisely or you may find yourself without the recipes you need, when you want them.  In addition, all recipes have a level requirement so you can’t simply unlock missile launchers (for example) at level 2 and blow everything up.  The mix of level locks, plus point unlocks, makes leveling a fairly exciting experience.  That being, every time you level you basically go “Sweet!  Now I can unlock that ____ I’ve been wanting to make!”

Mobs in Empyrion come in a couple different varieties.  You first have your basic non-aggressive indigenous creatures that will simply go about their business without a care in the world (until you shoot at them).  Next you have indigenous creatures that are hostile towards you and will attack you if you get too close.  It’s fairly difficult to tell the hostile mobs apart from the non-hostile mobs without actually risking being attacked, as they all look pretty mean, but once you gain the knowledge it makes the world a lot easier to navigate.  The third variety comes in the form of NPC structures that have turrets and enemy units, as well as drones that will hunt you down.  These drones can be fairly useful when lured away from their bases as, if you’re powerful enough to take them on, they always drop components you can use to craft equipment and machinery.

Finally we come down to the core of the game.  Does the game look good and sound good?  Well…  Yes, it does.  It’s not going to be winning any awards for realism and immersion, but when it’s stacked up beside other games in this genre it actually surpasses most of them.  Each creature has unique sounds, which I actually find very fitting to them and enjoy.  Music is well placed and fits the theme.  Distant planets and moons rise and set in the sky.  It’s actually very well polished for still being in Pre-Alpha.

So what’s my verdict?  Well, as I said, people will either love this game or hate it.  Personally I love it and I’d recommend it to anyone who likes games from the survival crafting genre.  That said, you'll just have to make up your own mind.

When you are new to the game, PvE will be challenging and fun, but once you learn the querks and short-comings of the game, PvE becomes really easy.
